fields: Presidential and vice-presidential elections occur every _____ ____ of _____ every ___ year.
second Monday of May, sixth
all elected officials, except those at the barangay level, start (and end) their terms of office on ____ of the election year.
June 30
a social or religious custom prohibiting or forbidding discussion of a particular practice or forbidding association with a particular person, place, or thing.
Taboo
-an activity or behavior that is considered completely unacceptable or forbidden.
Taboo
In Papua New Guinea: older women are also not supposed to eat ___ when pregnant, unmarried young men will receive the best food and do not have many food taboos
fish eggs
______ is a staple of the Brazilian diet. But not all ____are enjoyed by all Brazilians.
Seafood, fish
If you happen to be traveling to China, minding your ____ is the same as minding your manners.
chopsticks
In ____: After finishing meal at a restaurant, do not leave your chopsticks sticking up in the left-over rice at the bottom of your bowl.
China
_____ is not necessarily caring in Japanese culture.
Sharing
In Japan: If you do plan on sharing your meal, you must place the _____ on a small plate and then pass it to the recipient.
tasting morsel
In Russia: if you are hoping to court a lady at a restaurant, do not expect to go ____.
dutch (palibre or kkb)
Food taboos in India vary according to ____.
religion
For those that practice Hinduism, eating a ___ in prohibited.
cow

Islamic and Muslim families not only avoid ___ for religious reasons, they feel that ____ are bred in absolutely revolting conditions and are not worthy
of consumption.
pork, pigs
In ____: it is considered rude to accept the first offering of food. Politely decline at first, but when offered a second time — which you likely will be — feel free to accept.
Italy

In Jamaica, It is believed that if children eat ____ before they learn to speak, they will never talk. Eating half an ____ will make the child
grow into a thief and drinking ____ from a baby bottle will turn them into a drunkard.
chicken, egg, milk
they also feel particularly strongly about coconut milk. Another widely held belief is that children who drink this type of milk will make them unintelligent.
Nigerian Taboo

It is considered rude to rush through a meal or hurry your order along. You also never want to ask for a doggy-bag or leave food
on your plate, the implication being that you did not enjoy your meal.
French Taboos
A good leader is a ____ leader.
self actualized

A good political leader does not take what is similar to his views as facts and base his decisions on that. He uses reliable and unfiltered information to make judgments and to come up with resolutions.
Is fair and objective.

A good leader stands above any specific religious or political views of his own and is independent of any attachment to a specific agenda. His personal beliefs become his private matters and he learns to leave them out the door once he steps into a leadership role. In other words, his belief expands so that it includes everyone's beliefs.
Is moving above himself and serving the society

A good leader has been able to move above 
and beyond any egoistic and primitive need for power, attention, or establishing his personal agendas and works with the intention of good-for-all.
Is not seeking fame and attention

A good leader says it as it is even if it feels uncomfortable for many to hear it. He is not a people pleaser in a sense that he would say anything to please others even if that means manipulating or misguiding the public. It takes a lot of courage to do this and a good leader has that courage.
Is not into hiding the truth for the sake of looking good

A good leader is focused and does not get distracted. His goals, whether small or large, are reasonable and achievable and are directed towards the long term results not quick and temporary fixes that may backfire.

Is focused on specific, achievable, and measurable goals and demands 
outcomes

A good leader helps people understand that they are accountable for their society and its outcome and teaches them to make compromises and responsible choices. He does not support a sense of self-serving entitlement that has gone too far and is counter- productive for the society as a whole.
Encourages people to be accountable for their actions
A good leader understands that in order for the whole society to be a functional and healthy one, some adjustments need to be made and people need to learn to give some in order to gain some.
Does not pay attention to being politically correct but ethically so.
A good leader makes a sustainable promise and is a man of his words.
Does not make idealistic promises but realistic ones.
People know where they are standing with an authentic leader. He does not hide bad news just because it is uncomfortable to the public's ear.
Is honest even if it does not get approval

He realizes that in order for us to live in 
prosperity as a powerful and blessed country, reasonable steps need to be taken to make sure others achieve the same goals. He is aware that with power comes responsibility and that now more than ever, through technology, we are becoming more and more inner related, globally.
Thinks globally and acts locally

A good leader is secure enough with himself to take personal responsibility when one is needed. In other words, a good political leader has an internal locus of control while he is aware of the effects of the external forces.
Takes personal responsibility

A good political leader has a healthy emotional IQ and has learned to move above his emotions, conditionings, and his fixations to specific outcomes to think logically and globally. In other words, he is rational and in control of his emotions and when the public is going through the emotional roller coaster, he is there to guide them through it.
Remains level headed and has a sense of humor
A good leader is thirsty for factual, expert oriented and unbiased knowledge all the time and on all levels.
Has a curious mind

A leader that can be trusted does not take others down for himself to go up. He is more of a collaborator than a competitor. He tries to build bridges rather than destroy them. He is a natural mediator rather than one that creates conflict, tension, and separation.
Does not make himself look good by assaulting others
Characteristics of men/women that are socially constructed
Gender
The oldest religion in the world
Hinduism

Upper, Middle, Lower Classes

unemployed

Laborers

Nationality

Ethnicity

Exceptionality

Superior intelligence & slow learners
What is the specific learning disability in the communicative exceptionalities category?
Dyslexia
What are the two main types of sensory exceptionalities?
Auditory & Visual
What are the two kinds of behavioral exceptionalities?

- Emotionally disturbed
- Socially maladjusted
What subtype of behavioral exceptionalities include people with anxiety and depression?
Emotionally disturbed
People who have a hard time interacting with others socially are under what subtype of behavioral exceptionalities?
Socially maladjusted
What are the two subtypes of physical exceptionalities
Orthopedic and Mobility disabilities
Cerebral palsy is considered a mobility disability. T or F?
F, Orthopedic disability

(Can be either orthopedic or mobility)

All {{c1::orthopedic}} disabilities are {{c1::mobility}} disabilities, but not all {{c1::mobility}} disabilities are {{c1::orthopedic}} disabilities
Enumerate the 6 kinds of exceptionalities (ICSBPM)
Intellectual, Communicative, Sensory, Behavioral, Physical, Multiple

Istambay

Political Behavior

Political phenomenon
A type of dynasty wherein the seats are taken through intergenerational succession
Thin dynasty

Fat dynasty
What are the two chambers of the Legislative dept.?
Senate & The House of Representatives
The senate and the house of reps. are sometimes referred to as?
The upper and lower chamber of the legislative department
This job of the congress involves approving treaties and agreements
Ratification
This job of the congress involves proposing and debating laws
Legislation

Oversight

Speaker

Speaker

Speaker
This official of the house of reps. substitutes the speaker when they aren't available
Deputy speaker

Secretary general

Secretary General

Sergeant-at-arms

2nd Monday of May every 6 years
When do all elected officials begin their term?
June 30 of the election year
{{c1::Society}} is universal among human beings
Society

By providing fundamental avenues to the meaning of existence, rules of proper conduct, among others.

What is the act of composing and sending brief, electronic messages between two or more mobile phones.
Texting

to commit a crime or swindling.
What does SMS stand for?
Short Message Service
What does MMS stand for?
Multimedia Messaging Service
MMS vs SMS?
SMS - only text message, MMS - includes messages containing image, video, and sound content
limited to text-based messages

allows for the inclusion of multimedia content like images, videos, and audio, along with tex

familyhood

Local Public Services

Youth Volunteerism

A la Juventud Filipina

beliefs, social forms and traits
that defines a specific racial,

Greek word "politika" = affairs of the cities

social constructions that influence
a person’s life and development.
Social Phenomena

constituents.


Is this the job of the lower or upper house?
Lower house

Secretary general
{{c1::Anthropology}} is the study of humans – past and present.
It covers how people lived, how they evolved, and how they interact culturally and biologically.
Anthropology
Anthropology comes from the Greek words "{{c1::logos}}" meaning study and "{{c1::anthro}}" meaning man

Who defined anthropology "the study of humankind everywhere, throughout time, and seeks to produce useful generalizations about people and their behavior and to arrive at the fullest possible understanding of human diversity."?
Havilland, W. A. (1975)
Who is the father of Modern Anthropology?
Franz Boas
Who created the four-field structure of anthropology?
Franz Boas
What did Franz Boas propose?
That environment had an affect on our physical features
What are the four sub-fields of anthropology?

1) Archeology
2) Biological Anthropology
3) Cultural Anthropology
4) Linguistic Anthropology
What sub-field of anthropology studies beliefs, practices, and values across cultures?
Cultural Anthropology
What sub-field of anthropology looks at human evolution and genetics?
Biological Anthropology
What sub-field of anthropology studies language in its social context?
Linguistic Anthropology
Which sub-field in anthropology examines material remains to learn about past societies?
Archeology
What type of materials are examined in archeology (give at least 1)
Bones, artifacts, remains
What is the nature of anthropology?
Holistic and comparative—it seeks to understand humans in all times and places.
What are the 5 goals of anthropology?

1) To understand fossil record
2) To understand how humans adapt
3) To understand behavior of monkeys and apes in natural setting
4) To learn about biological and cultural aspects of humans
5) To apply anthropological knowledge to solve/prevent problems
How did Filipinos originate? (D'AIM)
Dawn Man, Aeta, Indones, Malays
{{c1::Sociology}} is the scientific study of human society, patterns of social relationships, interaction, and culture.
What is the nature of sociology?
Systematic and objective—it observes social behavior, institutions, norms, and how societies change.
Who is the father of Sociology?
Auguste Comte
What are the goals of sociology?

1) To understand how membership in one’s social group affects individual behavior
2) To understand the meaning and consequences of modernity, postmodernity and the new globalization.
3) Understand how cultures and institutions interact in different societies.
4) Understand the causes and consequences of social change in terms of general causes and effects as well as unique historical circumstances.
5)  Understand the causes and consequences of population composition and pressures and how population affects the environment and development of societies.
6) To provide information that reflects upon different policy initiatives
{{c1::Political Science}} deals with power, governance, public policies, political behavior, and institutions.
What is the nature of Political Science?
It is both theoretical and practical—it involves studying the law, constitutions, elections, and political ideologies.
Who is the Father of Modern Political Science?
Niccolò Machiavelli
Three main areas of political science?
Political theory, public law, and public administration
What is Political Theory?
Entire body of doctrines relating to origin, form, behavior, and purpose of the state.
What does Public Law study?
Legal structures like constitutions and courts.
What is Public Administration?
The management of government operations.
Four goals of political science?

1) Promote growth socially,economically, politically
2) Guide industrialization
3) Understand and manage social and political change
4) Analyze impact of government forms and policies
It is enjoying art,literature, music, or food
Culture
For scientists culture is?
Microorganisms growing in a lab
For anthropologists, what is culture?
The full range of learned human behavior patterns
Who said that "culture is that complex whole which includes knowledge, belief, art, morals, law, custom, and any other capabilities and habits acquired by man as a member of society"?
Edward B. Tylor
What are the layers of culture?

1) National or Societal Culture
2) Subculture
3) Cultural Universals
What are the five characteristics of culture?

Culture is:
1) Learned
2) Shared
3) Social
4) Cumulative
5) Dynamic
What later of culture includes languages, traditions, beliefs, and values passed down from generation to generation
National or Societal Culture
This layer of culture shared by people in a particular country or society
National or Societal Culture
Which layer of culture exists within a larger culture?
Subculture
In this layer of culture, people often maintain unique practices, languages, or traditions that set them apart
Subculture
This layer of culture is a small group within a larger culture
Subculture
These are behavior patterns of beliefs shared by all societies
Cultural Universals
This layer of culturue reflects basic needs and social patterns
Cultural Universals
An example of this culture are fiestas and respect for elderly (mano po)
National or Societal Culture
Examples of this culture are raising children in families and valuing privacy
Cultural Universals
Which characteristic of culture means that culture is not inherently biological
Culture is Learned
This characteristic of culture emphasizes that culture is discovered through interaction,observation, and instruction
Culture is Learned
This characteristic of culture says that culture binds people together through shared practices
Culture is Social
Which characteristic of culture says that culture is collectively practiced by people within a society
Culture is Shared
Culture exists within a group of people, not in {{c1::isolation}}
This characteristic of culture states that culture is built upon the experiences and knowledge of past generations
Culture is Cumulative
This characteristic of culture emphasizes the passing down of culture from ancestors to present
Culture is Cumulative
This characteristic of culture states that culture is always changing
Culture is Dynamic
This characteristic of culture highlights that culture can have new ideasm technologies, and influences to replace old ways.
Culture is Dynamic
{{c1::Culture}} is leaned behavior patterns, beliefs, values, and traditions
{{c1::Society}} is a group of people who interact and share a common culture
Sociology is dervied from "logos" meaning study and "{{c1::socius}}" meaning {{c2::group or partners}}
Sociology is done by examining the {{c1::dynamics}} of constiuent parts of societies such as communities, population
This includes studying social status, social movements, and change
Sociology
Who first coined the term "Sociology"?
Auguste Comte
When did Auguste Comte coin the term "sociology"?

Who said this “The ultimate aim of sociology is to improve man’s adjustment to life — to help individuals and societies better understand and manage their social environments for greater harmony and well-being.”
Samuel Koenig
According to Samuel Koenig, what is the ultimate aim of sociology?
to improve man’s adjustment to life
What type of perspective in sociology states that society is a system of interconnnnected parts tha work together in harmony to maintain a state of balance and social equilibrium
Functionalist Perspective
This perspective views society as composed of different groups and interests competing for power and resources
Conflict Perspective
This perspective in sociology asserts that an individual’s self-concept develops based on their perception of how others view them.
Symbolic - Interactionalist Perspective
The idea that our self-image forms based on how we think others see us.
Looking Glass Self
Who coined the idea "looking glass self"?
Charles Cooley
According to the symbolic-interactionalist perspective, our identity is shaped by?
social interaction
Political Science is derived from the words "{{c1::polis}}" meaning {{c2::state/city}} and "{{c1::scire}}" meaning {{c2::study}}
The aim of this is to strive to create an ideal government through the study and application of theories.
Political Science
What are the four components of state?

1) Territory
2) Population
3) Sovereignity
4) Government
Who is the Father of Political Science?
Aristotle
Who is the first political thinker to differentiate politics from morality?
Niccolo Machiavelli
Niccolo Machiavelli focused on {{c1::reality}} and what {{c1::needs}} to best achieve rather than consider what was right or wrong
This social science is concerned with the theory and practice of politics
Political Science
This social science is the study of state in past,present, future of political organizations and processes
Political Science
This is a body of doctrines relating to origin, form, bbehavior, and purpose of state
Political Theory
In which scope of political science do these belong: capitalism, liberalism, communism
Political Theory
This scope of political science covers constituiton, administrative, and international laws.
Public Law
This scope of political science includes the methods and techniques used in actual management of state by the government
Public Administration
This social science is the study of state and government
Political Science
A collective of individuals who share common geographical, cultural, or social ties
Society
Society functions as a {{c1::structured network}} in which members interact for mutual benefit, cooperation, and the progression of shared goals.

A society that survived by hunting animals and gathering edible plants
Foraging Societies
Foraging Societies are also called?
Hunting and Gathering Societies
A type of society in which food is obtained primarily by raising and taking care of animals
Pastoral Societies
A type of society that survived primarily through the growing of plants
Horticultural Societies
A society that uses plows and draft animals in growing food
Agricultural Societies
A society that depends on technology to produce its basic goods and services
Industrial Society
A society in which the economic emphasis is on providing services and information
Postindustrial Societies
{{c1::Subcultures}} are often based on ethnicity, religion, social class, or interests.
What are the 7 aspects of culture?

1. DYNAMIC, FLEXIBLE & ADAPTIVE
2. SHARED & CONTESTED
3. LEARNED THROUGH SOCIALIZATION OR ENCULTURATION
4. PATTEREND SOCIAL INTERACTIONS
5. INTEGRATED AND AT TIMES UNSTABLE
6. TRANSMITTED THROUGH SOCIALIZATION/ENCULURATION
7.REQUIRES LANGUAGE AND OTHER FORMS OF COMMUNICATION
Which aspect of culture states that culture changes over time?
Dynamic, Flexible & Adaptive
This aspect of culture says that culture evolves as people and societies face new challenges and experiences, and can adjust to new conditions while integrating new ideas.
Dynamic, Flexible & Adaptive
Which aspect of culture explains that it is shared by a group of people?
Shared & Contested
What aspect of culture recognizes that not everyone agrees with every norm or tradition, making it a source of unity and conflict?
Shared & Contested
According to the Shared & Contested aspect of culture, it can be both a source of?
unity and conflict
Culture is not inherited biologically; it is learned from families, schools, peers, media, and society through a lifelong process.
Learned Through Socialization or Enculturation
Which aspect of culture states that people acquire culture through learning and interaction rather than through biological inheritance?
Learned Through Socialization or Enculturation
What do we call the process of learning one’s own culture through family, peers, institutions, and society?
Enculturation
What do we call the process of adopting or borrowing aspects of another culture, often through contact and interaction?
Acculturation
Which aspect of culture explains that people’s interactions and behaviors follow shared patterns within society?
Patterned Social Interactions
Which aspect of culture states that culture is a system where all elements are connected?
Integrated and at Times Unstable
This aspect of culture explains that a change in one part of culture can affect the other parts.
Integrated and at Times Unstable
This aspect of culture says that although culture generally works harmoniously, it may become unstable when rapid changes occur.
Integrated and at time Unstable
This aspect of culture states that culture is passed from one generation to another through social learning, especially from parents, elders, teachers, and the media.
Transmitted through Socialization and Enculturation
What is the primary tool used to share and express culture?
Language
This aspect of culture states that language is the primary tool used to share and express culture.
Requires Language and Other Forms of Communication
This aspect of culture explains that communication can also be non-verbal, such as through symbols, rituals, or gestures.
Requires Language and Other Forms of Communication
Communication can also be {{c1::non-verbal}}, like symbols, rituals, or gestures.
It is judging another culture based upon the values and standards set in one’s own culture.
Ethnocentrism
It is a form of bias, where people tend to immediately judge another culture as 'bad' or 'wrong' based upon their actions, if their values are not aligned w ith their own beliefs.
Ethnocentrism
Terrorism and Hate Crimes are examples of {{c1::ethnocentrism}}. They take place when one religion or community believes that it is superior, and better than any other religion or community.
This refers to not judging a culture to our own standards of what is right or wrong, strange or normal.
Cultural Relativism
The question “Why do some cultures eat fried insects?” is an example of which cultural concept?
Cultural relativisim
The statement “Fried crickets are disgusting!” is an example of which cultural concept: ethnocentrism or cultural relativism?
Ethnocentrism
It is the belief that other cultures are superior to one’s own culture/ own culture is inferior.
Xenocentrism
An act of submitting oneself to the norms and conventions of a society
Conformity
Behavior which involves change in order to fit in
Conformity
Defined as a behavior, traits, beliefs or other characteristics that violates a norm and causes a negative reaction
Deviance
The definition of deviance is generally the same across culture time and situations. T or F?
F, varies widley
What  are the 2 criteria for Merton's Typology of Deviance

1. A person's adherence to cultural goals
2. A person's beliefs in how to attain their goals
Who created the Deviance Typology
Robert K. Merton
Enumerate the 5 types of deviance

1. Conformity
2. Innovation
3. Ritualism
4. Retreatism
5. Rebellion
These are group of people that follow the norms, and also trust the system which would help them achieve their goals
Conformity
The people that accept the society's goal, however, they reject the way on how to get the society's goal
Innovators
These are the people that reject the goals of the society but they still accept the means by doing the same things as conformists
Ritualists
Type of people who reject both the goals means of the society, which makes them deviant
Retreatism
These are people who are not satisfied with the current system, but instead they are the one who want to create new goals and means for society, which is deviant
Rebels

"A woman's nude picture displayed in the classroom or office is considered a deviance, but when displayed in an art exhibit it is not."

Which characteristic of deviance is this?
It is understood within its social context
"Gambling is not a deviance when now law prohibits it doing it is a deviance"
Deviance may change over time

"A single woman who leaves the home in the late evening without a chaperone or companion is considered a deviance but if a single man does it, it is not a deviance"

Which characteristic of deviance is this?
Deviance depends upon the status and role a person holds

"A celebrity gay who wears woman's apparel is funny the behavior is not a deviance. a minor who is drinking alcohol is a deviant but not in the case of an adult doing the same"

Which characteristic of deviance is this?
Deviance depends on the audience norm
What are the 2 main forms of deviance

A. According to violation of societal norm

B. According to acceptance of the goal
In this subform of deviance, the individual disagrees with the prescribed norms but is tolerated by others or his behavior is successfully concealed
Primary deviance
In this subtype of deviance, the individual is a criminal or deviant because of his previous deviant behavior
Secondary deviance
This labeling act is carried on throughout the person's life that forces him to commit delinquent acts
Secondary deviance
Give me 3 examples of primary deviance

- Cheating in the examination
- Throwing pieces of paper wrappers on the floor
- Throwing garbage on the street in an anti-literring area
- Smoking in a smoke-free area
- Urinating in a no-urinating zone
What are the 2 forms of deviance according to violation of societal norm?

1. Primary and secondary deviance
2. Individual and group deviation
In this subform of deviance, the person commits a deviant behavior of his own group or sub-culture
Individual deviance

{{c1::conflict}}, {{c1::unequal division of labor}},

Defined as smaller units that compose a society
Groups
A unit of interacting personalities with an interdependence of roles and status existing between members
Groups
A collection of individuals who have relations witih one anotehr that make them interdependent to some signficant degree
Social group
A necessary condition that exists within social groups because it is what enables its members to pursue shared goals
Interdependence
Profoundly defines our identity and as well as our roles in society
Social groups
What are the 3 main groups within society

- Primary group
- Secondary group
- Reference group
A {{c1::primary group}} is a small, intimate, less specialized group whose members engage in face to face and {{c2::emotion-based}} interaction over an extended period of time
In this type of group, members share personal and lasting relationships
Primary group
In this kind of group, the relationships are psychologically comforting to the individuals involved and provide a source of support
Primary group
Give me the 3 examples of some primary groups

1. Family
2. Friends 
3. Love relationships

A larger and less intimate and more
specialized groups where members engage
in an impersonal and objective-oriented
relationship for a limited time.
Secondary group

It something involves weak emotion and
interpersonal ties
Secondary group
Give me the two examples of secondary groups

1. School
2. Place of employment

A collection of people that we use as a standard of
comparison for ourselves regardless of whether we
are part of that group.
Reference group

A group to which we compare ourselves. It serves
as the standard to which we base our behavior and
attitudes.
Reference group

Are used in order to evaluate and
determine the nature of given individuals
Reference group
What are the two kinds of reference groups

- In-group
- Out-group
A group to which one belongs and with which one feels a sense of identity
In-group

A group to which one does not belong
and to which he or she may feel a sense
of competitiveness or hostility.
out-group
It is a social group with which an individual does not identify
out-group
What are the 3 types of reference group

1. Informal reference groups
2. Formal reference groups
3. Membership reference groups
This type of reference group is based on the group's shared interest and goals. Members react on a personal level
Informal reference groups

The web of social relationship that connects people in society

kinship

kinship
The origin background of a person in terms of family or nationality
Descent
It is a biological relationship
Descent
What are the three types of kinship?

Kinship by:
1. Blood
2. Marriage
3. Ritual
What are the 2 main types of kindship by blood?

1. Unilineal Descent
2. Bilateral Descent
This type of descent describes that a person is affiliated with a group of kin through descent links of ONE SEX only
Unilineal Descent
This type of descent means that a person considers relatives from both the mother’s and father’s sides as equally important.
Bilateral Descent
This type of descent affiliates a person with relatives from the father’s side only, tracing kinship through men.
Patrilineal Descent
This type of descent affiliates a person with relatives from the mother’s side only, tracing kinship through women.
Matrilineal Descent
It is a socially approved sexual and economic union
Marriage
Two types of marriage
Monogamy and Polygamy
It is a form of marriage where one man marries one woman
Monogamy
It is called plural marriage
Polygamy
Type of polygamic marraige where one man marries more than one woman
Polygyny
Type of polygamous marriage where one woman marries with more than one man
Polyandry
This is means the marriage of two or more women withtwo or more men
Cenogamy
It is marraige within clan
Endogamy
It is marriage outside clan
Exogamy
It is a privileged social relationship established by ritual such as that of godparents or fraternal orders

It is a family unit that consist of single couple or monogamous family: husband, wife, and their children
Nuclear Family
A family unit that consist of husband and wife and their children with relatives
Extended family
It is a family unit that consist of one or both parents who have children from a previous relationship but combined to form a new family
Reconstituted Family
Three types of family by Residence

1) Patrilocal Residence
2) Matrilocal Residence
3) Bilocal Residence
A family unit headed by one parent, either father or mother only, raising a child or children
Single Parent Family
Type of family by residence wherein son stays and daughter leaves so married couple lives with husband’s parents
Patrilocal residence
Type of family by residence wherein daughter stays son leaves, and couple lives with wife’s parents
Matrilocal Residence
Type of family by residence where either son or daughter leaves so that married couple lives either the wife’s or husband’s parents
Bilocal residence

It describes the socioeconomic levels of a society as “layers,” with the wealthiest and most powerful citizens being at the top.
Social stratitfication
The hierarchical status of a person is achieved through their effort and based economic system
Open Class System
When a group of people are given different opportunities depending on their characteristics
Closed Class System
Is the social position on is born into and personal characteristics beyond one control
Ascribed status
It is one’s social standing that depends on personal accomplishments.
Achieved status
The open class system involves 3 layers, namely:
Upper, middle, lower class
The caste system is what kind of class system?
Closed class system
The caste system involves?
Outcast, Sudra, Viasya, Kshatryia, and Bhramin
In the caste system, these are the priests, scholars, and philosophers who teach and study.
Brahmins
In the caste system, these are the warriors, rulers, and those concerned with defense and administration of the village
Kshatriyas
These are the traders, merchants and people involved in agricultural production in the caste system
Vaishyas
These are the peasants and common folk who make up the laborers and servants for the other castes in the caste system
Sudras
They are street sweepers and latrine cleaners
Outcast/Untouchable
This theory examines any social phenomenon through the lens that there is a natural human instinct towards conflict.
Conflict theory
This theory looks at society as a competition for limited resources
Conflict theoy
He saw society as being made up of individuals in different social classes who must compete for social, material, and political resources
Karl Marx
Marx is not saying that {{c1::conflict}} is good or bad, but instead that it is an unavoidable aspect of human nature and helps explain why things are the way they are.
